item.title: Honour in a Despotism, Principles of Despotism
The Laws from the Nature of Government
item.description: A monarchical or despotic government does not need the support of probity. The force of laws and the prince’s arm are sufficient to maintain the whole. But in a popular state, virtue is necessary. This is confirmed unanimously by historians and is extremely agreeable to the nature of things. A leader of a popular government needs virtue more than a monarch who can execute the laws by himself. A monarch can fix his mistakes by himself.
